title: Samarco restart is 'small beer' for Australia
text:
A restart of BHP and Vale's infamous Samarco operation would be "small beer" for iron ore markets, with very little impact on Australian exporters according to NAB's head of commodity research, Lachlan Shaw.

Samarco has been shut since a dam collapse killed 19 people in November 2015, but BHP and Vale were last week granted environmental approvals to restart the mine in late 2020.

The first phase of the restart envisages just 7 million to 8 million tonnes of annual iron ore production, well below the 29 million tonnes produced in fiscal 2015, with a gradual ramp-up over the subsequent decade.

''That is a little bit low,'' said Mr Shaw, when asked how the volumes forecast in the first phase of the restart compared to market expectations.

Samarco indicated it would be six years, and an investment decision, before production reached 15 million tonnes and production wouldn't ever go above 24 million tonnes.

''In a best case scenario, it is 10 years until they get to 21 million to 24 million tonnes per year, which is less than what they were producing previously," said Mr Shaw.
description: The restart of BHP and Vale's infamous Samarco operation in Brazil will have little impact on Australian iron ore miners, says NAB's head of commodity research.
